summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (USAO) personnel regarding the release of Jeffrey Epstein's redacted autopsy report under FOIA. It discusses coordination with the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) and details about specific redactions, including a photo of Epstein's hyoid bone.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: The sender of the initial email attaching the OCME Report of Autopsy, working from the White Plains, NY office.

events.title: Autopsy Report Prepared for FOIA Release
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney sends the OCME Report of Autopsy for Jeffrey Epstein to colleagues, indicating with boxes where redactions will be made for public release.

events.title: Discussion on Redacting Hyoid Bone Photo
events.description: An email notes a conversation with the General Counsel (GC) of OCME and raises a specific question about whether to redact a photo of Epstein's hyoid bone on page 12 of the report, in addition to closeup photos on page 13.

events.title: OCME Requests Copy of Redacted Report
events.description: An email states that OCME has asked for a copy of the redacted autopsy report, with a request to send it on the coming Friday.

events.title: Redacted Autopsy Report Sent
events.description: The redacted autopsy report is sent, noted as being included in a release to the Times (likely The New York Times).

locations.context: Office location of the Assistant United States Attorney involved in the correspondence.

keyFacts: The document is an internal email chain regarding the FOIA release of Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy report, showing procedural coordination between the U.S. Attorney's Office and the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME).

It reveals specific discussions about redacting a photograph of Epstein's hyoid bone (page 12) from the autopsy report, indicating sensitivity around the anatomical evidence related to the cause of death.
The correspondence confirms the autopsy report was released to The New York Times as part of the FOIA response.
The emails highlight ongoing legal and administrative handling of Epstein's case documents well after his death in 2019.
